availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

keywords.term: Medicine -- Formulae, receipts, prescriptions -- Early works to 1800.

div.head: NOTHING WITHOUT GOD

figure.figDesc: royal blazon or coat of arms
figure.q: HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE

div.p: THese are to give Notice unto all Persons, that this most Renowned and approved Dutch Doctor in many Nations, was born in that great and Famous City and University of Leyden in Holland Is now come to this Famous City of London, through the perswasion of many Eminent Persons, that knew in what great Credit he lived in Holland, for the Cure of all Venereal Distempers and Reliques thereof, hath been informed that thousands of People have been destroyed with these Diseases following. As curing the Running of the Reins, pain in making Water; In a short time, he cureth Carnosite, Ulcers, Cancers, Buboes, or Swelling in the Groin, this Disease hath several Symptoms, for sometimes it will lie with great pains in the Head, Arms, Shoulders, Legs, Sore. Throats, Ulcers in the Mouth or Pallat, as Scabs, Pustulaes, or Breakings out in the Head, Face or Neck, Nodes or Knots on the Shin-bone, by which many Families are ruined, sometimes it will break their rest after they are warm in their Bed with violent pains. I do Cure it with all its attendants, so private and so secret by Ten or Fifteen Doses without hindering their business, all Venereal Distempers or Reliques; that a Man shall not perceived it by his Wife, nor the Wife by her Husband, and so perfectly that it shall never break out again, and none of their Relations shall take any notice of their Distempers to the admiration of the Patient: He is a Person of that Quality, that will not promise more than he can perform; he will undertake none unless he can Cure them.

HE will restore them again to their former health by pleasant safe Cordial Medicines, in which i • no danger, that kills the Poyson of the Pox in the Blood, without Fluxing or making Sic • this is sufficient for such as love their Health, although they have been Sweated, Fluxed, and Lance • by others, I shall confirm by actions, as I relate here by words.

I Do also help such as have lost their Seed, and make the Spirit of Married people rejoyce, bein • lost by what occasion soever, and cause them to be as Sprightly as ever, this I can testifie by • great many here in this Town.

I Could mention many more Effects and Operations tha • I have done; but for brevity sake, an • not to trouble the Reader too much, I have omitted them, being you may have my Advice at a •… times for nothing, and be informed of many Cures more, not mentioned here; as I can make appe •… by the Testimonies of several in this Town. As also in Germany, Hamburgh, Bremen, Paris, whe •… I have been Three years a Practitioner at the Kings Hospital, and got there great Experience in th •… Practice of the French Pox, and several other Diseases; as a rare secret in Consumptions, Fever • and Fistulaes. I also cure any manner of Gout, let the humour be what it will, I presently give eas •… I can dissolve the Stones either in Bladder, or Gravel in Kidneys. Therefore come unto me fo • your own good, and loose not this Bill, that you may not be attacht with the Vulgar here, I nee • not here particularize, there being so many that can testifie it, that I have Cured, which were le • by others. Neglect not your own Health, since God hath been pleased to send a means.
ANd if and one live not here, they need not upon that account miss my assistance, for I can sen • them such proper Medicines as they may Cure themselves.

ANd that the Learned and Experienced in the knowledges of Physick, and remedies may be satisfied with this present writing, I have thought fit to inform them, with what Medicaments • make (with Gods assistance) the Cures above-mentioned, that they may judge of their excellency▪ and afterwards perswade the publick to make use of them without fear, but with surety and advantag • to their own health. These remedies are first a Mercury, sweet or cleansing, gentle, which the Ancients have called the Celestial Eagle, for to express the virtue thereof, which I make of a Mercur •
animated out of Sulphur, of Mars, of Antimony, and of Gold, whereof they take the qualities fo • to produce all I have said of the French Pox and its incidents. The Second, is Panchymagogue,
• vegetable made within all the rules of Chimistry. The Third, a cleansing Antimony, drawn ou • of a potent Emetique, by a method rare and unknown. The Fourth, is a special Stomachique, o • an extract Stomachal of a virtue most particular. The Fifth, is Diuritick, which is a Water or Liquor upon which the Stomack, the Veins Mezaraique or Liver have no power. The Sixth, is th •
Balsamum of the Lungs of our Fore-fathers, or Quintessence of Sulphur prepared with an unknow • method. The Seventh, is a Solaris Sudorifick of a new invention. The Eighth, is an Emetiqu •
without violence, which cleanseth without Pain, or Griping, or any bad Symptome. All these remedies are prepared by my Artists in London, which will justifie the goodness and experience of them▪ The Patient if he pleaseth, may have his Physick Galenically of me, as they like best.

HE Cureth all Persons that are Bursten Bellies or Ruptures, either in Men, Women, or Children▪ only with some outward Application, and all without pain or danger. I shall require nothing for my Counsel, Medicine, or Pains, till they have been cured half a year.
ANd if any one cannot come, let him but send his true Water or Urine, and he gives his Judgmen • to the best of his skill wherewith God hath endued him.

☞ This Leydens Dutch Doctor, Oculist, Chirurgion, and Rupture Master , who liveth over against the May-pole in the Strand, Six doors from Sommer set-house, is to be spoken with every day from Nine in the Morning till Nine at Night, where you will see Six Candles burning in a coloured Flag Lanthorn of Orange, white and blew, with this Subscription under neath. Gonsal • Gerardts, A Dutch Doctor, No Cure no Money. Which Lanthorn hangs between the Whit • Flying Horse, an Habbadasher of Hats, and the Coffee Sign. Also these Printed Bills pasted 〈…〉 in the long Entry, where you may privately come in.
